title: The Wind and the Sun
moral: Gentleness and kindness can achieve what force and aggression cannot.
haiku: Warm rays melt the chill\nStrength in calm, not stormy gusts\nCloak falls in still peace.

title: The Fox and the Crow
moral: Beware of those who flatter you only to get what they want.
haiku: Fox with hungry grin\nPraise lifts pride, and cheese falls down\nTruth hides in sweet words.

title: The Donkey and His Shadow
moral: Arguing over trivial matters can cause you to lose what truly matters.
haiku: Shadow in the sun\nQuarrel steals the path ahead\nDonkey walks alone.

title: The Donkey in the Lion's Skin
moral: Pretending to be something you're not may fool others briefly, but the truth always reveals itself.
haiku: In lion’s costume\nDonkey brays and truth is known\nBe true to yourself.

title: The Crow and the Raven
moral: True admiration comes from being yourself, not from pretending to be someone else.
haiku: Feathers not your own\nWon’t bring the praise you long for\nShine in your own light.

title: The Bundle of Sticks
moral: Unity is strength; when people stand together, they cannot be broken.
haiku: Sticks bound, firm and strong\nAlone they snap one by one\nTogether, they hold.

title: The Wolf and the Crane
moral: Helping the ungrateful can lead to danger and disappointment.
haiku: Crane pulled out the bone\nWolf's thanks came with biting teeth\nAid earns no reward.

title: The Hawk and the Nightingale
moral: Words and wisdom can be more powerful than strength in moments of danger.
haiku: Nightingale pleads, sings\nHawk trades hunger for her voice\nMercy earns a song.

title: The Lion and the Boar
moral: Choosing peace over pride can prevent unnecessary harm and lead to mutual respect.
haiku: Two beasts face to fight\nVultures watch from skies above\nPeace drinks, pride steps back.

title: The Fox and the Goat
moral: Always think ahead and be cautious about whose advice you follow.
haiku: Fox with clever scheme\nGoat leaps in, trust seals his fate\nPlan before you leap.

title: The Travelers and the Plane Tree
moral: True worth is not always visible at first glance; even simple things can provide great value.
haiku: Shaded from the sun\nComplaints blind to present gifts\nStillness speaks of worth.

title: The Two Pots
moral: True friendship respects each other's strengths and limitations.
haiku: Brass and clay afloat\nRiver tests their fragile bond\nKindness leads them home.

title: The Dog and the Bone
moral: Greed can lead to losing what you already have.
haiku: Bone clutched in his jaws\nGreedy bark, a splash below\nAll for naught, it's gone.

title: The Fisherman and the Little Fish
moral: A small gain today is better than a big promise tomorrow.
haiku: Tiny fish pleads hope\nBut the sea won’t promise back\nSure catch feeds today.

title: The Bull and the Frog
moral: Trying to be something you're not can lead to foolishness and harm.
haiku: Bull's size spurs a puff\nFrog stretches past his limit\nBurst pride, lesson learned.

title: The Oak and the Reeds
moral: True strength lies in adaptability and humility, not just in standing firm.
haiku: Storm shakes forest still\nOak resists and breaks apart\nReeds bow, rise again.

title: The Miser and the Gold
moral: Wealth is meaningless if it's never used or shared.
haiku: Gold buried in ground\nNever touched, then stolen fast\nEmpty riches lost.

title: The Fox and the Monkey
moral: True leadership is earned through wisdom and integrity, not through boasting and show.
haiku: Monkey boasts of might\nFalls short chasing empty praise\nFox shows truth with grace.

title: The Fox and the Hedgehog
moral: Sometimes, one reliable strategy is better than many clever tricks.
haiku: Fox with tricks galore\nHedgehog curls with quiet strength\nSafe in spiky calm.

title: The Lion and the Dolphin
moral: True alliances are founded on understanding and respecting each other's unique strengths and limitations.
haiku: Lion on the shore\nDolphin dances in the waves\nEach realm has its bounds.

title: The Fisher and the Snake
moral: Kindness is noble, but it must be tempered with wisdom, as not all creatures can change their nature.
haiku: A snake in the net\nSaved by hands both kind and brave\nStill, it struck again.

title: The Eagle and the Beetle
moral: Even the smallest creature can teach a powerful lesson when respect is lacking.
haiku: Small beetle stands tall\nStrength bows to clever wisdom\nRespect conquers pride.

title: The Old Woman and the Doctor
moral: Greed and dishonesty will ultimately be exposed and lead to disgrace.
haiku: Eyes blinded by trust\nTruth returns with clearer sight\nGreed unmasked by light.

title: The Gnat and the Bull
moral: True importance lies in one’s actions, not in seeking attention or validation.
haiku: Buzzing on the horn\nGnat seeks praise the bull won't give\nSize means not respect.

title: The Donkey and His Masters
moral: Wishing for change without appreciating the present can lead to worse outcomes.
haiku: From one load to next\nDonkey longs for kinder hands\nLearns to bear his lot.

title: The Wolf and the Kid
moral: Listening to wise advice can prevent trouble that cleverness alone might not overcome.
haiku: A kid strays too far\nWolf’s fangs near—but wit and calls\nBring the herd to save.

title: The Ant and the Chrysalis
moral: Don't judge others by appearances; growth often happens quietly and unseen.
haiku: Stillness hides the change\nWings unfold from quiet strength\nNow she soars with grace.

title: The Oak and the Vine
moral: True strength comes from supporting each other, even when our strengths are different.
haiku: Vine climbs the oak tall\nStorms bend but do not break them—\nTogether they stand.

title: The Rabbit and the Hound
moral: Those with more at stake often fight harder and smarter to succeed.
haiku: Hound runs for a meal\nRabbit flees with all her might\nLife fuels faster feet.

title: The Two Frogs
moral: It's important to think ahead and be cautious before leaping into something, no matter how tempting it may seem.
haiku: Tempting waters shine\nwisdom halts the hasty leap\nsafe stream flows with thought.

title: The Crow and the Swan
moral: True beauty comes from being yourself, not from trying to be someone else.
haiku: Black feathers still gleam\nenvy fades with self-love's light\nbeauty in the truth.

title: The Wild Boar and the Fox
moral: It's better to be prepared and not need your defenses than to need them and not be prepared.
haiku: Tusks honed every day\ndanger comes when least expected\nready strength prevails.

title: The Camel and the Floating Sticks
moral: Fear often comes from misunderstanding, and when we look closer, it may vanish.
haiku: Sticks drift on still pool\nfear dissolves with closer look\ntruth calms thirsty heart.

title: The Owl and the Grasshopper
moral: Respecting others' needs brings harmony to everyone.
haiku: Songs must know their place\nwisdom speaks in quiet tones\npeace blooms when we care.

title: The Farmer and the Snake
moral: Kindness must be tempered with wisdom, for not all creatures return it with gratitude.
haiku: Cold snake, warming fire\nfangs betray a kind-hearted\nnature can’t be changed.

title: The Mouse and the Frog
moral: Bad decisions and unkind actions can lead to trouble for everyone involved.
haiku: Tied by tricks, they flew\nlaughter turned to shared danger\ntrust broke in midair.

title: The Miller, His Son, and Their Donkey
moral: Trying to please everyone often leads to pleasing no one, not even yourself.
haiku: Voices all around\nlost the donkey, lost their way\nchoose your path with heart.

title: The Horse and the Stag
moral: In seeking revenge, be careful not to sacrifice something more valuable—like your freedom.
haiku: Help came with a price\nfreedom traded for control\nmeadow lost to pride.

title: The Travellers and the Bear
moral: True friendship is proven through actions, especially in times of danger.
haiku: Bear’s breath on still face\nsilence speaks of loyalty\ntrust lies where hearts stay.

title: The Miser
moral: Wealth has no value if it is not used to benefit oneself or others.
haiku: Gold hid in the ground\nnever spent, never enjoyed\nstolen without worth.

title: The Dog and the Wolf
moral: Freedom is more valuable than comfort obtained at the cost of liberty.
haiku: Collar glints in light\ncomfort comes with a small chainn\nwolf walks free, unfed.

title: The Swan and the Goose
moral: Every creature has unique qualities that serve a purpose and deserve respect.
haiku:
Swan glides, grace preserved—
beauty saves from hunters' snare,
goose learns to respect.

title: The Farmer and the Cranes
moral: Ignoring warnings and taking without regard leads to consequences.
haiku: Cranes mocked scare and bell\nngreed blind to the farmer's trap\ncaught, they flew no more.

title: The Hare and the Tortoise
moral: Steady effort and determination can triumph over speed and arrogance.
haiku: Hare sleeps in the sun\ntortoise moves with quiet strength\nvictory through pace.

title: The Wolf and the Lamb
moral: Those who seek to harm will always find an excuse, regardless of reason or truth.
haiku: Wolf blames the pure lamb\nexcuses cloak hungry fangs\ndog drives lies away.

title: The Man and the Satyr
moral: Inconsistency in behavior can lead others to question your trustworthiness.
haiku: Breath cools, breath then warms\nsatyr shuns the shifting ways,\ntruth lives in the still.

title: The Wolf and the Shepherd
moral: It is foolish to trust those whose true nature opposes your interests, no matter how friendly they appear.
haiku: Wolf guards the sheepfold\npromises mask hungry teeth\ntruth hides in the dark.

title: The Donkey and the Lapdog
moral: Trying to be someone you're not only leads to trouble—value your own strengths instead.
haiku: Donkey leaps with hope\nnot all love is shown the same\nstrength has its own worth.

title: The Dog in the Manger
moral: Just because something is of no use to you doesn't mean you should prevent others from benefiting from it.
haiku: The dog blocks the hay\nThough she cannot eat a bite\nLet others partake.

title: The Lion, the Bear, and the Fox
moral: While the strong fight over their pride, the clever often walk away with the prize.
haiku: Lion, bear in strife\nFighting blinds them to the goal\nFox takes the reward.

title: The Dog and the Sheep
moral: Seeking rewards from those who don't owe you anything is unfair and misguided.
haiku: Guard dog wants his due\nBut the sheep owe him no debt\nJustice sets it right.

title: The Cat and the Rooster
moral: Those who understand their purpose cannot be easily misled or silenced by deceit.
haiku: Cat whispers deceit\nBut the proud rooster won't yield\nHis crow greets the dawn.

title: The Stag and the Pool
moral: What appears beautiful may not be what truly sustains or protects us.
haiku: Stag loves his antlers\nBut when danger comes to call\nLegs are what save him.

title: The Donkey and the Load of Salt
moral: Tricks may offer short-term relief, but true effort brings lasting reward.
haiku: Donkey tricks the stream\nSalt dissolves, the load feels light\nSponges weigh him down.

title: The Fisherman and His Nets
moral: Persistence and patience often lead to success, even after initial failure.
haiku: Empty nets at first\nTry again, the sea provides\nPatience earns reward.

title: The Shepherd and the Sea
moral: Chasing uncertain riches can lead to great loss; sometimes, the simple life is the wiser choice.
haiku: Shepherd seeks the sea\nLeaves behind his steady life\nStorms teach him regret.

title: The Gnat and the Lion
moral: Even the smallest can defeat the mighty, but arrogance can lead to a sudden fall.
haiku: Gnat mocks mighty king\nWins the fight, but pride blinds him\nSpider ends his flight.

title: The Owl and the Raven
moral: True wisdom lies not in how loudly one speaks, but in knowing when to act and when to be silent.
haiku: Raven boasts aloud\nBut owl’s silence saves the day\nWisdom whispers truth.

title: The Farmer and His Sons
moral: Unity brings strength, while division leads to weakness and failure.
haiku: One stick breaks with ease\nBound together, they hold strong\nStand as one, endure.

title: The Swallow and the Other Birds
moral: Heed warnings early to prevent greater harm later.
haiku: Seeds sown in silence\nWarnings fall on deafened ears\nTraps close with sharp wings.

title: The Boasting Traveler
moral: True worth is shown by actions, not empty words.
haiku: Words float on the breeze\nSilent truth waits to be seen\nDeeds reveal the soul.

title: The Dog and His Master’s Dinner
moral: Loyalty and integrity are worth more than temptation.
haiku: Loyal heart resists\nTemptation’s sweet fleeting call\nTrust feeds soul, not greed.

title: The Fox and the Hedgehog
moral: A single effective plan is better than many ineffective ones.
haiku: One sharp, steady trick\nOutwits a hundred falters\nSimplicity wins.

title: The Donkey and His Purchaser
moral: The true nature of a creature is revealed by the company it keeps.
haiku: Friends show who we are\nIdle shadows shape the mind\nChoose companions wise.

title: The Goose That Laid the Golden Eggs
moral: Greed can destroy the source of true wealth and bring loss instead.
haiku: Golden eggs each dawn\nGreed's knife ends the steady gift\nEmpty nest remains.

title: The Young Man and the Swallow
moral: Do not rush decisions based on limited signs; patience and foresight bring wisdom.
haiku: One bird in the sky\nFalse spring warms the restless heart\nCold winds still return.

title: The Milkmaid and the Pail
moral: Do not count your chickens before they hatch.
haiku: Dreams spill on the ground\nFuture fades with lost present\nStep by step, proceed.

title: The Fox and the Cat
moral: One reliable plan is better than many indecisive ones.
haiku: One trick well practiced\nOutshines a hundred that fail\nFocus saves the day.

title: The Camel and the Floating Sticks
moral: Even the strongest can be brought down by a small added burden.
haiku: Strong legs bear great loads\nLast stick breaks the proud camel\nLimits must be known.

title: The Weasel and the Mice
moral: Once trust is broken by deception, it is hard to regain.
haiku: Silent weasel waits\nTrust shattered by cunning lies\nEyes watch, hearts beware.

title: The Hawk and the Nightingale
moral: It is wiser to keep a sure thing than risk it for uncertain gain.
haiku: Held in fierce talons\nSmall prize beats uncertain hunt\nWisdom keeps the sure.

title: The Crow and the Sheep
moral: If you allow someone to take advantage of your kindness, they will keep taking more.
haiku: Rest turns to damage\nKindness worn like fragile wool\nSet limits to keep.

title: The Bees and the Drones
moral: Only those who contribute through hard work deserve to share in the rewards.
haiku: Honey made with care\nIdlers claim without labor\nEffort earns the sweet.

title: The Mice in Council
moral: Good plans require courage and willingness to take risks to succeed.
haiku: Plans ring with promise\nBut who will face the dangerous claws\nCourage must answer.

title: The Bear and the Bees
moral: Losing your temper can lead to greater pain than the original offense.
haiku: Anger stings like bees\nRage brings pain beyond the bite\nPatience soothes the soul.

title: The Old Woman and the Doctor
moral: Dishonesty and greed will ultimately lead to exposure and punishment.
haiku: Greed hides in shadows\nTruth reveals the stolen gold\nJustice finds its way.

title: The Hawk, the Falcon, and the Pigeons
moral: Beware of inviting greater dangers while trying to avoid smaller ones.
haiku: Fear invites the wolf\nProtector turns predator\nrust must be guarded.

title: The Monkey and the Two Cats
moral: Greed and stubbornness can cause you to lose everything to others’ cunning.
haiku: Cats fight for their bread\nMonkey eats while they argue\nShare or lose your prize.

title: The Vine and the Oak
moral: True strength lies in flexibility and adapting to challenges, not rigid pride.
haiku: Oak breaks in the storm\nVine bends with the restless wind\nStrength in soft whispers.

title: The Wind and the Sun
moral: Gentle kindness is often more effective than force or aggression.
haiku: Wind blows with fierce might\nSun warms with a gentle light\nSoft wins every fight.

title: The Laborer and the Nightingale
moral: True wisdom lies in kindness, discernment, and letting go of regret.
haiku: Kindness freely given\nTruth and patience guide the heart\nLet go, grow, and learn.

title: The Frogs and the Well
moral: Think carefully before making decisions to avoid traps that are hard to escape.
haiku: Frogs gaze at deep wells\nBeauty hides the hidden trap\nChoose the safe refuge.

title: The Weasel and the Mice
moral: Deceptive tricks may succeed once, but trust is lost and not easily regained.
haiku: Flour hides the truth\nCunning fails when wisdom wakes\nTrust once broken, gone.

title: The Fisherman and His Nets
moral: Patience and perseverance often lead to success, even when results seem delayed.
haiku: Nets cast in silence\nHope waits beneath restless waves\nPatience brings the catch.

title: The Boasting Traveller
moral: True worth is shown through actions, not empty words or boasts.
haiku: Words float on the breeze\nDeeds stand firm like mountain stone\nShow, do not just proclaim.

title: The Peacock and the Crane
moral: Being useful and capable is more valuable than mere outward beauty.
haiku: Feathers bright and proud\nYet flight belongs to the plain\nGrace outshines the show.

title: The Donkey in the Lion’s Skin
moral: Pretending to be someone you’re not will only lead to embarrassment; true worth comes from being yourself.
haiku: Lion’s skin worn proud\nDonkey’s bray breaks the false guise\nTruth shines through the mask.

title: The Eagle and the Jackdaw
moral: Know your strengths and accept who you are instead of trying to be something you’re not.
haiku: Jackdaw dreams so high\nCaught where wool and pride entwine\nTrue self learns to fly.

title: The Fox and the Leopard
moral: Cleverness and quick thinking are more valuable than outward beauty in times of danger.
haiku: Spots shine in the sun\nFox slips unseen through shadows\nBrains outlast the gleam.

title: The Man and the Lion
moral: Every story reflects the teller’s perspective, so be cautious about believing only your own version.
haiku: Stories shape our truth\nThe Lion’s tale left untold\nWisdom hears them both.

title: The Ants and the Dung Beetle
moral: Enjoy the present, but prepare wisely for the challenges ahead.
haiku: Sun warms carefree days\nWinter’s chill demands foresight\nWork guards future’s flame.

title: The Mouse, the Frog, and the Hawk
moral: Deception harms both the deceiver and the deceived, leading to shared downfall.
haiku: Tied by false kindness\nDeceiver and the deceived\nBoth fall to the hawk.

title: The Lark and Her Young Ones
moral: Pay attention to signs and act promptly before it's too late.
haiku: Waiting on the wind\nSigns tell when to take to flight\nSwift wings find new fields.

title: The Lion and the Boar
moral: Conflict weakens all parties, but cooperation ensures survival and strength.
haiku: Foes clash on dry earth\nVultures wait with hungry eyes\nPeace feeds both in need.

title: The Cat, the Rooster, and the Young Mouse
moral: Appearances can be deceiving; trust your instincts and look beyond the surface.
haiku: Silent fur deceives\nLoud crow guards the timid mouse\nTruth hides in sound’s shade.

title: The Fisher and the Little Fish
moral: It is better to accept a small, certain gain than to risk it for a greater, uncertain reward.
haiku: Small fish in my hand\nPromises float in the stream\nSurety feeds the soul.

title: The Dog in the Manger
moral: Do not selfishly block others from what you do not need yourself.
haiku: Dog guards empty hay\nCows watch hungry, waiting close\nSharing brings no loss.

title: The Lion, the Fox, and the Deer
moral: Be cautious of deceivers and learn from the wise to avoid danger.
haiku: Lion’s cunning snare\nFox reads footprints, deer walks blind\nWisdom guards the path.

title: The Dog, the Rooster, and the Fox
moral: True friends watch out for each other and protect one another from harm.
haiku: Rooster warns from high\nDog guards with fierce loyalty\nFox flees empty-pawed.

title: The Bear and the Two Travellers
moral: A true friend stays by your side in danger, not abandoning you when trouble comes.
haiku: Friend climbs up the tree\nOther lies still, brave and calm\nTrue friend stands firm, close.

title: The Crow and the Pitcher
moral: With patience and cleverness, even the hardest problems can be solved.
haiku: Pebbles drop with care\nWater rises, thirst is quenched\nMind finds its own way.

title: The Honest Woodcutter
moral: Honesty is always rewarded, even when tempted to claim more than is rightfully yours.
haiku: True heart shines like gold\nHonest hands hold what is theirs\nSpirit gifts the rest.
